paragraph: Tf any of the powerful men seated around the table found this disrespectful tone objectionable, aglance at Tagge was sufficient to dissuade them from mentioning it.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The dim prison reeked of rancid oil and stale Iubricants, a veritable metallic charnel house. Threepioendured the discomfiting atmosphere as best he could. It was a constant battle to avoid being thrown by every unexpected bounce into the walls or into a fellow machine.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: To conserve power—and also to avoid the steady stream of complaints from his taller companion— Artoo Detoo had shut down all exterior functions. He lay inert among a pile of secondary parts, sublimely unconcemed at the moment as to their fate.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Will this never end?” Threepio was moaning as another violent jolt roughly jostled the inhabitants of the prison. He had already formulated and discarded half a hundred horrible ends. He was certain only that their eventual disposition was sure to be worse than anything he could imagine.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Then, quite without warning, something more unsettling than even the most battering bump tookplace. The sandcrawler’s whine died, and the vehicle came to a halt—almost as if in response to Threepio’s query. A nervous buzz rose from those mechanicals who still retained a semblance of sentience as they speculated on their present location and probable fate.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: At least Threepio. was no longer ignorant of his captors or of their likely motives. Local captives had explained the nature of the quasi-human mechanic migrants, the jawas. Traveling in their enormous mobile fortress-homes, they scoured the most inhospi-table regions of Tatooine in search of valuable minerals—and salvageable machinery. They had never been seen outside of their protective cloaks and sandmasks, so no one knew exactly what they looked like. But they were reputed to be extraordinarily ugly. Threepio did not have to be convinced.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Leaning over his still-motionless companion, he began a steady shaking of the barrellike torso. Epidermalsensors were activated on the Artoo unit, and the lights on the front side of the little robot began a sequential awakening.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Wake up, wake up,” Threepio urged. “We've stopped someplace.” Like several of the other, more imaginative robots, his eyes were warily scanning metal walls, expecting a hidden panel to slide aside

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: at any moment and a giant mechanical arm to come probing and fumbling for him.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “No doubt about it, we’re doomed,” he recited moumfully as Artoo righted himself, returning to full activation. “Do you think they'll melt us down?” He became silent for several] minutes, then added, “It’s this waiting that gets to me.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Abruptly the far wall of the chamber slid aside and the blinding white glare of a Tatooine morning tushed in on them. Threepio’s sensitive photoreceptors were hard pressed to adjust in time to preventserious damage.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Several of the repulsive-looking jawas scrambled agilely into the chamber, still dressed in the same swathings and filth Threepio had observed on them before. Using hand weapons of an unknown design, they prodded at the machines. Certain of them, Threepio noted with a mental swallow, did not stir.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Ignoring the immobile ones, the jawas herded those still capable of movement outside, Artoo and Threepio among them. Both robots found themselves part of an uneven mechanical line.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Shielding his eyes against the glare, Threepio saw that five of them were arranged alongside the huge sandcrawler. Thoughts of escape did not enter his mind. Such a concept was utterly alien to a mechanical. The more intelligent a robot was, the more ab-horrent and unthinkable the concept. Besides, had he tried to escape, built-in sensors would have detected the critical logic malfunction and melted every circuit in his brain.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Instead, he studied the small domes and vaporators that indicated the presence of a larger underground human homestead. Though he was unfamiliar with this type of construction, all signs pointed to a modest, if isolated, habitation. Thoughts of being dismembered for parts or slaving in some high-temperature mine slowly faded. His spirits rose correspondingly.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Maybe this won’t be so bad after all,” he murmured hopefully. “If we can convince these bipedal

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: vermin to unload us here, we may enter into sensible human service again instead of being melted into slag.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Artoo’s sole reply was a noncommittal chirp. Both machines became silent as the jawas commenced scurrying around them, striving to straighten one poor machine with a badly bent spine, to disguise a dent or scrape with liquid and dust.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: As two of them bustled about, working on his sandcoated skin, Threepio fought to stifle an expressionof disgust. One of his many human-analog functions was the ability to react naturally to offensive odors. Apparently hygiene was unknown among the jawas. But he was certain no good would come of pointing this out to them.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Small insects drifted in clouds about the faces of the jawas, who ignored them. Apparently the tiny individualized plagues were regarded as just a different sort of appendage, like an extra arm or leg.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: So intent was Threepio on his observation that he failed to notice the two figures moving toward them from the region of the largest dome. Artoo had to nudge him slightly before he looked up.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The first man wore an air of grim, semiperpetual exhaustion, sandblasted into his face by too many years of arguing with a hostile environment. His graying hair was frozen in tangled twists like gypsumhelicites. Dust frosted his face, clothes, hands, and thoughts. But the body, if not the spirit, was still powerful.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Proportionately dwarfed by his uncle’s wrestlerlike body, Luke strode slump-shouldered in his shadow, his present attitude one of dejection rather than exhaustion. He had a great deal on his mind, and ithad very little to do with farming. Mostly it involved the rest of his life, and the commitment made by his best friend who had recently departed beyond the blue sky above to enter a harsher, yet more rewarding ca~- reer.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The bigger man stopped before the assembly and

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: entered into a peculiar squeaky dialogue with the jawa in charge. When they wished it, the jawas could be understood.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke stood nearby, listening indifferently. Then he shuffled along behind his uncle as the latter began inspecting the five machines, pausing only to mutter an occasional word or two to his nephew. It was hard to pay attention, even though he knew he ought to be learning.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Luke—oh, Luke!” a voice called.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Turning away from the conversation, which consisted of the lead jawa extolling the unmatched vir-tues of all five machines and his uncle countering with derision, Luke walked over to the near edge of the subterranean courtyard and peered down.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A stout woman with the expression of a misplaced sparrow was busy working among decorative plants. She looked up at him. “Be sure and tell Owen that if he buys a translator to make sure it speaks Bocce, Luke.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Turning, Luke looked back over his shoulder and studied the motley collection of tired machines. “It looks like we don’t have much of a choice,” he called back down to her, “but [ll remind him anyway.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: She nodded up at him and he tumed to rejoin his uncle.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Apparently Owen Lars had already come to a decision, having settled on a small semi-agriculturalrobot. This one was similar in shape to Artoo Detoo, save that its multiple subsidary arms were tipped with different functions. At an order it had stepped out of the line and was wobbling along behind Owen and the temporarily subdued jawa.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: _ Proceeding to the end of the line, the farmer’s eyes narrowed as he concentrated on the sand-scoured but still flashy bronze finish of the tall, humanoid Threepio.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “I presume you function,” he grumbled at the robot. “Do you know customs and protocol?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: ‘Do I know protocol?” Threepio echoed as the

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: farmer looked him up and down. Threepio was determined to embarrass the jawa when it came to sell-ing bis abilities. “Do I know protocol! Why, it’s my primary function. I am also well—”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Don’t need a protocol ’droid,” the farmer snapped dryly.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “IT don’t blame you, sit,” Threepio rapidly agreed. “IT couldn’t be more in agreement. What could be more of a wasteful luxury in a climate like this? For someone of your interests, sir, a protocol *droid would be a useless waste of money. No, sir—versatility is my middle name. See Vee Threepio—Vee for versatility—at your service. I’ve been programmed forover thirty secondary functions that require only . . .”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “IT need,” the farmer broke in, demonstrating imperious disregard for Threepio’s as yet unenumeratedsecondary functions, “a ’droid that knows something about the binary language of independently programmable moisture vaporators.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Vaporators! We are both in luck,” Threepio countered. “My first post-primary assignment was in programming binary load lifters. Very similar in construction and memory-function to your vaporators. You could almost say...”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke tapped his uncle on the shoulder and whispered somethiing in his ear. His uncle nodded, then looked back at the attentive Threepio again.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Do you speak Bocce?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Of course, sir,” Threepio replied, confident for a change with a wholly honest answer. “It’s like a second language to me. “I’m as fluent in Bocce as—”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The farmer appeared determined never to allow him to conclude a sentence. “Shut up.” Owen Lars looked down at the jawa. “T’ll take this one, too.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Shutting up, sir,” responded Threepio quickly, hard put to conceal his glee at being selected.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Take them down to the garage, Luke,” his uncle instructed him. “I want you to have both of them cleaned up by suppertime.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke looked askance at his uncle. “But I was go-

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: ing into Tosche station to pick up some new power converters and...”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Don’t lie to me, Luke,” his uncle warned him sternly. “I don’t mind you wasting time with your idle friends, but only after you’ve finished your chores. Now hop to it—and before supper, mind.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Downcast, Luke directed his words irritably to Threepio and the small agricultural robot. He knew better than to argue with his uncle.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Follow me, you two.” They started for the garage as Owen entered into price negotiations with the jawa.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Other jawas were leading the three remaining machines back into the sandcrawler when something letout an almost pathetic beep. Luke turned to see a Artoo unit breaking formation and starting toward him. It was immediately restrained by a jawa wielding a control device that activated the disk sealed onthe machine’s front plate. ,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke studied the rebellious droid curiously. Threepio started to say something, considered the circum-stances and thought better of it. Instead, he remained silent, staring straight ahead.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A minute later, something pinged sharply nearby. Glancing down, Luke saw that a head plate had popped off the top of the agricultural ’droid. A grinding noise was coming from within. A second later themachine was throwing internal components all over the sandy ground.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Leaning close, Luke peered inside the expectorating mechanical. He called out, “Uncle Owen! Theservomotor-central on this cultivator unit is shot. Look .. .” He reached in, tried to adjust the device, and pulled away hurriedly when it began a wild sparking. The odor of crisped insulation and corroded circuitry filled the clear desert air with apungency redolent of mechanized death.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Owen Lars glared down at the nervous jawa. “What kind of junk are you trying to push on us?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The jawa responded loudly, indignantly, while si-

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: multaneously taking a couple of precautionary steps away from the big human. He was distressed that the man was between him and the soothing safety of the sandcrawler.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Meanwhile, Artoo Detoo had scuttled out of the group of machines being led back toward the mobile fortress. Doing so turned out to be simple enough, since all the jawas had their attention focused on the argument between their leader and Luke’s uncle.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Lacking sufficient armature for wild gesticulation, the Artoo unit suddenly let out a high whistle, then broke it off when it was apparent he had gained Threepio’s attention.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Tapping Luke gently on the shoulder, the tall. *droid whispered conspiratorially into his ear. “If I might say so, young sir, that Artoo unit is a real bargain. In top condition, I don’t believe these creatures have any idea what good shape he’s really in.Don’t let all the sand and dust deceive you.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke was in the habit of making instant decisions —for good or bad—anyway. “Uncle Owen!” he called.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Breaking off the argument without taking his attention from the jawa, his uncle glanced quickly athim. Luke gestured toward Artoo Detoo. “We don’t want any trouble. What about swapping this—” he indicated the burned-out agricultural ’droid—‘for that one?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The older man studied the Artoo unit professionally, then considered the jawas. Though inherentlycowards, the tiny desert scavengers could be pushed too far. The sandcrawler could flatten the homestead —at the risk of inciting the human community to lethal vengeance.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Faced with a no-win situation for either side if he pressed too hard, Owen resumed the argument for show’s sake before gruffly assenting. The head jawa consented reluctantly to the trade, and both sides breathed a mental sigh of relief that hostilities

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: had been avoided. While the jawa bowed and whined with impatient greed, Owen paid him off.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Meanwhile, Luke had led the two robots toward an opening in the dry ground. A few seconds later they were striding down a ramp kept clear of drifting sand by electrostatic repellers.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Don’t you ever forget this,’ Threepio muttered to Artoo, leaning over the smaller machine. “Why I stick my neck out for you, when all you ever bring me is trouble, is beyond my capacity to comprehend.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The passage widened into the garage proper, which was cluttered with tools and sections of farming machinery. Many looked heavily used, some to the pointof collapse. But the lights were comforting to both *droids, and there was a hominess to the chamber which hinted at a tranquillity not experienced by either machine for a long time. Near the center of thegarage was a large tub, and the aroma drifting from it made Threepio’s principal olfactory sensors twitch.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke grinned, noting. the robot’s reaction. “Yes, it’s a lubrication bath.” He eyed the tall bronze robot appraisingly. “And from the looks of it, you could useabout a week’s submergence. But we can’t afford that so you'll have to settle for an afternoon.” Then Luke turned his attention to Artoo Detoo, walking up to him and flipping open a panel that shielded numerous gauges,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “As for you,” he continued, with a whistle of surprise, “I don’t know how you’ve kept running. Notsurprising, knowing the jawas’ reluctance to part with any erg-fraction they don’t have to. It’s recharge time for you.” He gestured toward a large power unit.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Artoo Detoo followed Luke’s gesture, then beeped once and waddled over to the boxy construction. Finding the proper cord, he automatically flipped open a panel and plugged the triple prongs into his face. ;

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio had walked over to the large cistern, which was filled almost full with aromatic cleansing

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: oil. With a remarkably humanlike sigh he lowered himself slowly into the tank.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “You two behave yourselves,” Luke cautioned them as he moved to a small two-man skyhopper. A powerful little suborbital spacecraft, it rested in the hangarsection of the garage-workshop. “I’ve got work of my own to do.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Unfortunately, Luke’s energies were still focused on his farewell encounter with Biggs, so that hours later he had finished few of his chores. Thinking about his friend’s departure, Luke was running a caressing hand over the damaged port fin of the *hopper—the fin he had damaged while running down an imaginary Tie fighter in the wrenching twists and turns of a narTow canyon. That was when the projecting ledge hadclipped him as effectively as an energy beam.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Abruptly something came to a boil within him. With atypical violence he threw a power wrench across a worktable nearby. “It just isn’t fair!” he declared to no one in particular. His voice dropped disconsolately. “Biggs is right. I'll never get out of here. He’s planning rebellion against the Empire, and I’m trapped on a blight of a farm.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “I beg your pardon, sir.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke spun, startled, but it was only the tall "droid, Threepio. The contrast in the robot was striking compared with Luke’s initial sight of him. Bronze-coloredalloy gleamed in the overhead lights of the garage, cleaned of pits and dust by the powerful oils.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Is there anything I might do to help?” the robot asked solicitously.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke studied the machine, and as he did so some of his anger drained away. There was no point in yelling cryptically at a robot.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “I doubt it,” he replied, “unless you can alter time and speed up the harvest. Or else teleport me off this sandpile under uncle Owen’s nose.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Sarcasm was difficult for even an extremely sophisticated robot to detect, so Threepio considered thequestion objectively before finally replying, “T don’t

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: think so, sir. I’m only a third-degree ’droid and not very knowledgeable about such things as transatomic physics.” Suddenly, the events of the past couple of days seemed to catch up with him all at once. “As a matter of fact, young sir,” Threepio went on while looking around him with fresh vision, “I’m not even sure which planet I’m on.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke chuckled sardonically and assumed a mocking pose. “If there’s a bright center to this universe, you’re on the world farthest from it.”’

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Yes, Luke sir.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The youth shook his head irritably. “Never mind the ‘sir’-—it’s just Luke. And this world is called Tatooine.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio nodded slightly. “Thank you, Luke s— Luke. I am See Threepio, human-droid relations specialist.” He jerked a casual metal thumb back toward the recharge unit. “That is my companion, Artoo Detoo.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Pleased to meet you, Threepio,” Luke said easily. “You too, Artoo.” Walking across the garage, he checked a gauge on the smaller machine’s front panel, then gave a grunt of satisfaction. As he began unplugging the charge cord he saw something whichmade him frown and lean close.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Something wrong, Luke?” Threepio inquired.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke went to a nearby tool wall and selected a small many-armed device. “I don’t know yet, Threepio.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Returning to the recharger, Luke bent over Artoo and began scraping at several bumps in the small *droid’s top with a chromed pick. Occasionally he jerked back sharply as bits of corrosion were flicked into the air by the tiny tool.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio watched, interested, as Luke worked. “There’s a lot of strange carbon scoring here of a type Pm not familiar with. Looks like you’ve both seen a lot of action out of the ordinary.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Indeed, sir,” Threepio admitted, forgetting to drop the honorific. This time Luke was too absorbed else-

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: where to correct him. “Sometimes I’m amazed we’re in as good shape as we are.” He added as an afterthought, while still shying away from the thrust of Luke’s question, “What with the rebellion and all.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Despite his caution, it seemed to Threepio that he must have given something away, for an almost jawalike blaze appeared in Luke’s eyes. “You know aboutthe rebellion against the Empire?” he demanded.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “In a way,” Threepio confessed reluctantly. “The rebellion was responsible for our coming into your service. We are refugees, you see.” He did not add from where.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Not that Luke appeared to care. “Refugees!” Then IJ did see a space battle!” He rambled on rapidly, excited. “Tell me where you’ve been—in howmany encounters. How is the rebellion going? Does the Empire take it seriously? Have you seen many ships destroyed?” .

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “A bit slower, please, sir,” Threepio pleaded. “You misinterpret our status. We were innocent bystanders. Our involvement with the rebellion was of the most marginal nature.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “As to battles, we were in several, I think. It is difficult to tell when one is not directly in contact with the actual battle machinery.” He shrugged neatly. “Beyond that, there is not much to say. Remember, sir, I am little more than a cosmeticizedinterpreter and not very good at telling stories or relating histories, and even less proficient at embellishingthem. J am a very litera] machine.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke turned away, disappointed, and returned to his cleaning of Artoo Detoo. Additional scraping turned up something puzzling enough to demand his full attention. A small metal fragment was tightly lodged between two bar conduits that would normally form a linkage. Setting down the delicate pick, Luke switched to a larger instrument.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Well, my little friend,” he murmured, “you’ve got something jammed in here real good.” As he pushed

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: and pried Luke directed half his attention to Threepio. “Were you on a star freighter or was it—”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Metal gave way with a powerful crack, and the recoil sent Luke tumbling head over heels. Getting tohis feet, he started to curse—then froze, motionless.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The front of the Artoo unit had begun to glow, exuding a three-dimensional image less than one-third of a meter square but precisely defined. The portrait formed within the box was so exquisite that in a couple of minutes Luke discovered he was out of breath——because he had forgotten to breathe.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Despite a superficial sharpness, the image flickered and jiggled unsteadily, as if the recording had been made and installed with haste. Luke stared at the foreign colors being projected into the prosaic atmosphere of the garage and started to form a question.But it was never finished. The lips on the figure moved, and the girl spoke—or rather, seemed to speak, Luke knew the aural accompaniment was generated somewhere within Artoo Detoo’s squat torso.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Obi-wan Kenobi,” the voice implored huskily, “help me! You’re my only remaining hope.” A burst of static dissolved the face momentarily. Then it coalesced again, and once more the voice repeated, “Obi-wan Kenobi, you’re my only remaining hope.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: With a raspy hum the hologram continued. Luke sat perfectly still for a long moment, considering what he was seeing, then he blinked and directed his words to the Artoo unit.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “What’s this all about, Artoo Detoo?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The stubby ‘droid shifted slightly, the cubish portrait shifting with him, and beeped what soundedvaguely like a sheepish reply.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio appeared as mystified as Luke. “What is that?” he inquired sharply, gesturing at the speaking portrait and then at Luke. “You were asked a question. What and who is that, and how are you origi-nating it—and why?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The Artoo unit generated a beep of surprise, for all the world as if just noticing the hologram. This

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: was followed by a whistling stream of information.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio digested the data, tried to frown, couldn’t, and strove to convey his own confusion via the tone of his voice, “He insists it’s nothing, sir, Merely a mailfunction—old data. A tape that should have been erased but was missed. He insists we pay it no mind.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: That was like telling Luke to ignore a cache of Durindfires he might stumble over in the desert. “Who is she?” he demanded, staring enraptured at the hologram. “She’s beautiful.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “IT really don’t know who she is,” Threepio confessed honestly. “I think she might have been a pas-senger on our last voyage. From what I recall, she was a personage of some importance. This might have something to do with the fact that our Captain was attaché to—”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke cut him off, savoring the way sensuous lips formed and reformed the sentence fragment. “Is there any more to this recording? It sounds like it’s incomplete.” Getting to his feet, Luke reached out for theArtoo unit.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The robot moved backward and produced whistles of such frantic concern that Luke hesitated and held off reaching for the internal controls.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio was shocked. “Behave yourself, Artoo,” he finally chastised his companion. “You're going to get us into trouble.” He had visions of the both of them being packed up as uncooperative and shipped back to the jawas, which was enough to make him imitate a shudder.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Tt’s all right—he’s our master now.” Threepio indicated Luke. “You can trust him. I feel that he hasour best interests in mind.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Detoo appeared to hesitate, uncertain. Then he whistled and beeped a long complexity at his friend.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Well?” Luke prompted impatiently.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio paused before replying. ‘““He says that he is the property of one Obi-wan Kenobi, a resident of this world. Of this very region, in fact. The sentence

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: fragment we are hearing is part of a private message intended for this person.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio shook his head slowly. “Quite frankly, sir, I don’t know what he’s talking about, Our last master was Captain Colton. I never heard Artoo mention a prior master. [’ve certainly never heard of an Obiwan Kenobi. But with all we’ve been through,” he con-cluded apologetically, “I’m afraid his logic circuits have gotten a bit scrambled. He’s become decidedly eccentric at times.” And while Luke considered this tum of events, Threepio took the opportunity to throw Artoo a furious look of warning.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Obi-wan Kenbi,” Luke recited thoughifully, His expression suddenly brightened. “Say . . . I wonder if he could be referring to old Ben Kenobi.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Begging your pardon,” Threepio gulped, astonished beyond measure, “but you actually know of sucha person?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Not exactly,” he admitted in a more subdued voice. “I don’t know anyone named Obi-wan—but old Ben lives somewhere out on the fringe of the Western Dune Sea. He’s kind of a local character— a hermit. Uncle Owen and a few of the other farmers say he’s a sorcerer.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “He comes around once in a while to trade things. I hardly ever talk to him, though. My uncle usually runs him off.” He paused and glanced across at the small robot again. “But I never heard that old Ben owned a "droid of any kind. At least, none that I ever heard tell of.” :

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke’s gaze was drawn irresistibly back to the hologram. “I wonder who she is. She must be important—especially if what you told me just now istrue, Threepio. She sounds and looks as if she’s in some kind of trouble. Maybe the message is important. We ought to hear the rest of it.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: He reached again for the Artoo’s internal controls, and the robot scurried backward again, squeaking a blue streak.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “He says there’s a restraining separator bolt that’s

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: circuiting out his self-motivation components.” Threepio translated. “He suggests that if you move the bolthe might be able to repeat the entire message,” Threepio finished uncertainly. When Luke continued to stare at the portrait, Threepio added, more loudly “Sirf” -

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke shook himself. “What . . . ? Oh, yes.” He considered the request. Then he moved and peered into the open panel. This time Artoo didn’t retreat.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “I see it, I think. Well, I guess you’re too small to run away from me if I take this off. I wonder what someone would be sending a message to old Ben for.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Selecting the proper tool, Luke reached down into the exposed circuitry and popped the restraining bolt free. The first noticeable result of this action was that the portrait disappeared.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke stood back. “There, now.” There was an uncomfortable pause during which the hologram showedno sign of returning. “Where did she go?” Luke finally prompted. “Make her come back. Play the entire message, Artoo Detoo.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: An innocent-sounding beep came from the robot. Threepio appeared embarrassed and nervous as he translated. “He said, “What message?’ ”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio’s attention turned half angrily to his companion. “What message? You know what message!The one you just played a fragment of for us. The one you’re hauling around inside your recalcitrant, rust-ridden innards, you stubborn hunk of junk!”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Artoo sat and hummed softly to himself.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “T’m sorry, sir,” Threepio said slowly, “but he shows signs of having developed an alarming flutter in his obedience-rational module. Perhaps if we—”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A voice from down a corridor interrupted him. “Tuke ... oh, Luke—come to dinner!”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke hesitated, then rose and turned away from the puzzling little *droid. “Okay,” he called, “I’m coming, Aunt Beru!” He lowered his voice as he spoke to Threepio. “See what you can do with him. Pil be

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: back soon.” Tossing the just-removed restraining bolt on the workbench, he hurried from the chamber.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: As soon as the human was gone, Threepio whirled on his shorter companion. “You'd better consider playing that whole recording for him,” he growled, with a suggestive nod toward a workbench laden with dismembered machine parts. “Otherwise he’s liable to take up that cleaning pick again and go digging for it. He might not be too careful what he cuts through if he believes you’re deliberately withholding something from him.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A plaintive beep came from Artoo.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “No,” Threepio responded, “I don’t think he likes you at all.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A second beep failed to alter the stern tone in the taller robot’s voice. “No, I don’t like you, either.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: LI IV

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: LUKE’S Aunt Beru was filling a pitcher with blue liquid from ‘a refrigerated container. Behind her, in the dining area, a steady buzz of conversation reached to the kitchen.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: She sighed sadly. The mealtime discussions between her husband and Luke had grown steadily more acrimonious as the boy’s restlessness pulled him indirections other than farming. Directions for which Owen, a stolid man of the soil if there ever was one, had absolutely no sympathy.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Returning the bulk container to the refrigerator unit, she placed the pitcher on a tray and hurried back to the dining room. Bern was not a brilliant woman, but she possessed an instinctive understanding of her important position in this household. She functioned like the damping rods in a nuclear reactor. As long as she was present, Owen and Luke would continue

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: to generate a lot of heat, but if she was out of their presence for too long—boom!

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Condenser units built into the bottom of each plate kept the food on the dining-room table hot as she hurried in. Immediately, both men lowered their voices to something civilized and shifted the subject. Beru pretended not to notice the change.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “I think that Artoo unit might have been stolen, Uncle Owen,” Luke was saying, as if that had been the topic of conversation all along.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: His uncle helped himself to the milk pitcher, mumbling his reply around a mouthful of food. “The jawashave a tendency to pick up anything that’s not tied down, Luke, but remember, they’re basically afraid of their own shadows. To resort to outright theft, they'd have to have considered the consequences of being pursued and punished. Theoretically, their minds shouldn’t be capable of that. What makes you think the ‘droid is stolen?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “For one thing, it’s in awfully good shape for a discard. It generated a hologram recording while I wascleaning—” Luke tried to conceal his horror at the slip. He added hastily, “But that’s not important. The reason I think it might be stolen is because it claims to be the property of someone it calls Obi-wan Kenobi.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Maybe something in the food, or perhaps the milk, caused Luke’s uncle to gag. Then again, it might have been an expression of disgust, which was Owen’s way of indicating his opinion of that peculiar personage. In any case, he continued eating without looking up at his nephew.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke pretended the display of graphic dislike had never happened. “I thought,’ he continued determinedly, “it might have meant old Ben. The first nameis different, but the last is identical.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: When his uncle steadfastly maintained his silence, Luke prompted him directly. “Do you know who he’s talking about, Uncle Owen?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Surprisingly, his uncle looked uncomfortable instead

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: of angry. “It’s nothing,” he mumbled, still not meeting Luke’s gaze. “A name from another time.” Hesquirmed nervously in his seat. “A name that can only mean trouble.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke refused to heed the implied warning and pressed on. “Is it someone related to old Ben, then? I didn’t know he had any relatives.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “You stay away from that old wizard, you hear me!” his uncle exploded, awkwardly substituting threat for reason.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Owen...” Aunt Beru started to interject gently, but the big farmer cut her off sternly.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Now, this is important, Beru.” He turned his attention back to his nephew. “I’ve told you aboutKenobi before. He’s a crazy old man; he’s dangerous and full of mischief, and he’s best left well alone.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Beru’s pleading gaze caused him to quiet somewhat. “That ’droid has nothing to do with him.Couldn’t have,” he grumbled half to himself. “Recording—huh! Well, tomorrow I want you to take theunit into Anchorhead and have its memory flushed.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Snorting, Owen bent to his half-eaten meal with determination. “That will be the end of this foolishness. I don’t care where that machine thinks it camefrom. I paid hard credit for it, and it belongs to us now.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “But suppose it does belong to someone else” Luke wondered. “What if this Obi-wan person comes looking for his ’droid?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: As expression between sorrow and a sneer crossed his uncle’s seamed face at a remembrance. “He won't. I don’t think that man exists anymore. He died about the same time as your father.” A huge mouthful of hot food was shoveled inward. “Now forget about it.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Then it was a real person,” Luke murmured, staring down at his plate. He added slowly, “Did he knowmy father?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “T said forget about it,” Owen snapped. “Your only worry as far as those two "droids are concerned is

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: having them ready for work tomorrow. Remember, the last of our savings is tied up in those two. Wouldn’t even have bought them if it wasn’t so near harvest.” He shook a spoon at his nephew. “In the morning I want you to have them working with the irrigation units up on the south ridge.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “You know,” Luke replied distantly, “I think these *droids are going to work out fine. In fact, I—’ He hesitated, shooting his uncle a surreptitious glare. “I was thinking about our agreement about me staying on for another season.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: His uncle failed to react, so Luke rushed on before his nerve failed. “If these new ’droids do workout, I want to transmit my application to enter the Academy for next year.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Owen scowled, trying to hide his displeasure with food. “You mean, you want to transmit the application next year—after the harvest.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “You have more than enough “droids now, and they’re in good condition. They'll last.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “*Droids, yes,” his uncle agreed, “but *droids can’t replace a man, Luke. You know that. The harvest is when I need you the most. It’s just for one more season after this one.” He looked away, bluster and anger gone now.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke toyed with his food, not eating, saying nothing.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Listen,” his uncle told him, “for the first time we’ve got a chance for a real fortune. We'll make enough to hire some extra hands for next time. Not ’droids— people. Then you can go to the Academy.” He fumbled over words, unaccustomed to pleading. “I needyou here, Luke. You understand that, don’t you?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “It’s another year,” his nephew objected sullenly. “Another year.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: How many times had he heard that before? How many times had they repeated this identical charade with the same result?

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Convinced once more that Luke had come round

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: to his way of thinking, Owen shrugged the objection off. “Time will pass before you know it.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Abruptly Luke rose, shoving his barely touched plate of food aside. “That’s what you said last year when Biggs left.” He spun and half ran from the room.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Where are you going, Luke?” his aunt yelled worriedly after him.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke’s reply was bleak, bitter. “Looks like I’m going nowhere.” Then he added, out of consideration for his aunt’s sensibilities, “I have to finish cleaning those ’droids if they’re going to be ready to work tomorrow.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Silence hung in the air of the dining room after Luke departed. Husband and wife ate mechanically. Eventually Aunt Beru stopped shoving her food around her plate, looked up, and pointed out earnestly, “Owen, you can’t keep him here forever. Most of his friends are gone, the people he grew up with. The Academy means so much to him.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Listlessly her husband replied, “I’!l make it up to him next year. J promise. We’ll have money—or maybe, the year after that.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Luke’s just not a farmer, Owen,” she continued firmly. “He never will be, no matter how hard you try to make him one.” She shook her head slowly. “He’s got too much of his father in him.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: For the first time all evening Owen Lars looked thoughtful as well as concerned as he gazed down the passage Luke had taken. “That’s what I’m afraid of,” he whispered.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke had gone topside. He stood on the sand watching the double sunset as first one and then the other of Tatooine’s twin suns sank slowly behind the distant range of dunes. In the fading light the sands turned gold, russet, and flaming red-orange before advancing night put the bright colors to sleen for anotherday. Soon, for the first time, those sands would blos-

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: som with food plants. This former wasteland would see an eruption of green.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The thought ought to have sent a thrill of anticipation through Luke. He should have been as flushedwith excitement as his uncle was whenever he described the coming harvest. Instead, Luke felt nothing but a vast indifferent emptiness. Not even the prospect of having a lot of money for the first time in his life excited him. What was there to do with money in Anchorhead—anywhere on Tatooine, for that matter?

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Part of him, an increasingly Jarge part, was growing more and more restless at remaining unfulfilled.This was not an uncommon feeling in youths his age, but for reasons Luke did not understand it was much stronger in him than in any of his friends.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: As the night cold came creeping over the sand and up his legs, he brushed the grit from his trousers and descended into the garage. Maybe working on the *droids would bury some of the remorse a little deeper in his mind. A quick survey of the chamber showed no movement. Neither of the new machines was in sight. Frowning slightly, Luke took a small control box from his belt and activated a couple of switches set into the plastic.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A low hum came from the box. The caller produced the taller of the two robots, Threepio. In fact, he gave a yell of surprise as he jumped up behind the skyhopper.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke started toward him, openly puzzled. “What are you hiding back there for?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The robot came stumbling around the prow of the craft, his attitude one of desperation. It occurred to Luke then that despite his activating the caller, the Artoo unit was still nowhere to be seen.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The reason for his absence—or something related to it-came pouring unbidden from Threepio. “It wasn’t my fault,” the robot begged frantically. “Please don’t deactivate -me! I told him not to go, but he’s

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: faulty. He must be malfunctioning. Something has totally boiled his logic circuits. He kept babbling onabout some sort of mission, sir. I never heard a 1obot with delusions of grandeur before. Such thingsshouldn’t even be within the cogitative theory units of one that’s as basic as an Artoo unit, and...”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “You mean ....?” Luke started to gape.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Yes, sir... he’s gone.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “And I removed his restraining coupling myself,” Luke muttered slowly. Already he could visualize his uncle’s face. The last of their savings tied up in these *droids, he had said.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Racing out of the garage, Luke hunted for nonexistent reasons why the Artoo unit should go ber-serk. Threepio followed on his heels.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: From a small ridge which formed the highest point close by the homestead, Luke had a panoramic view of the surrounding desert. Bringing out the precious macrobinoculars, he scanned the rapidly darken-ing horizons for something small, metallic, threelegged, and out of its mechanical mind.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio fought his way up through the sand to stand beside Luke. “That Artoo unit has always caused nothing but trouble,” he groaned. “Astromech *droids are becoming too iconoclastic even for me to understand, sometimes.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The binoculars finally came down, and Luke commented matter-of-factly, “Well, he’s nowhere in sight.”He kicked furiously at the ground. “Damn it—how could I have been so stupid, letting it trick me into removing that restrainer! Uncle Owen’s going to killme.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Bepging your pardon, sir,” ventured a hopeful Threepio, visions of jawas dancing in his head, “but can’t we go after him?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke turned. Studiously he examined the wall of black advancing toward them. “Not at might. It’s too dangerous with all the raiders around. Pm not too concerned about the jawas, but sandpeople . . . no,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: not in the dark. We'll have to wait until morning to try to track him.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A shout rose from the homestead below. “Luke— Luke, are you finished with those ’droids yet? I'm turning down the power for the night.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “All right!” Luke responded, sidestepping the question. “I'll be down in a few minutes, Uncle Owen!” Turning, be took one last look at the vanished horizon. “Boy, am I in for it!” he muttered, “That little ’droid’s going to get me in a lot of trouble.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Oh, he excells at that, sir.” Threepio confirmed with mock cheerfulness. Luke threw him a sour look, and together they turned and descended into the garage.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Luke ... Luke!” Still rubbing the morning sleep from his eyes, Owen glanced from side to side, loosening his neck muscles. “Where could that boy be loaf-ing now?” he wondered aloud at the lack of response. There was uo sign of movement in the homestead, and he had already checked above.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Luke!” he yelled again. Luke, luke, luke... the name echoed teasingly back at him from the homestead walls. Turning angrily, he stalked back into thekitchen, where Beru was preparing breakfast.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Have you seen Luke this morning?” he asked as softly as he could manage.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: She glanced briefly at him, then returned to her cooking. “Yes. He said he had some things to do before he started out to the south ridge this morning, sohe left early.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Before breakfast?” Owen frowned worriedly. “That’s not like him. Did he take the new “droids with him?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “T think so. I’m sure I saw at least one of them with him.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Well,” Owen mused, uncomfortable but with nothing to really hang imprecations on, “he’d better havethose ridge units repaired by midday or there'll be hell to pay.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: An unseen face shielded by smooth white metal emerged from the half-buried life pod that now formed the backbone of a dune slightly higher than its neighbors. The voice sounded efficient, but tired.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Nothing,” the inspecting trooper muttered to his several companions. “No tapes, and no sign of babitation.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Powerful handguns lowered at the information that the pod was deserted. One of the armored men tured, calling out to an officer standing some distance away. “This is definitely the pod that cleared the rebel ship, sir, but there’s nothing on board.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Yet it set down intact,” the officer was murmuring to himself. “It could have done so on automatics, but if it was a true malfunction, then they shouldn’t have been engaged.” Something didn’t make sense.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Here’s why there’s nothing on board and no hint of life, sir,” a voice declared.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The officer turned and strode several paces to where another trooper was kneeling in the sand. He held up an object for the officer’s inspection. It shone in the sun.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “°Droid plating,” the officer observed after a quick glance at the metal fragment. Superior and underling exchanged a significant glance. Then theireyes turned simultaneously to the high mesas off to the north.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Gravel and fine sand formed a gritty fog beneath the landspeeder as it slid across the rippling wasteland of Tatooine on humming repulsors. Occasionallythe craft would jog slightly as it encountered a dip or slight rise, to return to its smooth passage as its pilot compensated for the change in terrain.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke leaned back in the seat, luxuriating in unaccustomed relaxation as Threepio skillfully directedthe powerful landcraft around dunes and rocky outcrops. “You handle a landspeeder pretty well, for amachine,” he noted admiringly.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Thank you, sir,” a gratified Threepio responded,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: his eyes never moving from the landscape ahead. “I was not lying to your uncle when I claimed versatility as my middle name. In fact, on occasion I have been called upon to perform unexpected functions in circumstances which would have appalled my designers.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Something pinged behind them, then pinged again.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke frowned and popped the speeder canopy. A few moments of digging in the motor casing eliminated the metallic bark.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “How’s that?” he yelled forward.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio signaled that the adjustment was satisfactory. Luke turned back into the cockpit and closedthe canopy over them again. Silently he brushed his wind-whipped hair back out of his eyes as his attention returned to the dry desert ahead of them.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Old Ben Kenobi is supposed to live out in this general direction. Even though nobody knows exactly where, I don’t see how that Artoo unit could have come this far so quickly.” His expression was downcast. “We must have missed him back in the dunessomewhere. He could be anywhere out here. And Uncle Owen must be wondering why I haven't called in from the south ridge by now.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio considered a moment, then ventured, “Would it help, sir, if you told him that it was my fault?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke appeared to brighten at the suggestion. “Sure ... he needs you twice as much now. Probably he’ll only deactivate you for a day or so, or give you a partial memory flush.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Deactivate? Memory flush? Threepio added hastily, “On second thought, sir, Artoo would stil! be around if you hadn’t removed his restraining module.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: But something more important than fixing responsibility for the little robot’s disappearance was onLuke’s mind at the moment. “Wait a minute,” he advised Threepio as he stared fixedly at the instrumentpanel. “There’s something dead ahead on the metal scanner. Can’t distinguish outlines at this distance, but

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: judging by size alone, it could be our wandering *droid. Hit it.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The landspeeder jumped forward as Threepio engaged the accelerator, but its occupants were totallyunaware that other eyes were watching as the craft increased its speed.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Those eyes were not organic, but then, they weren’t wholly mechanical, either. No one could say for certain, because no one had ever made that intimate astudy of the Tusken Raiders—known less formally to the margin farmers of Tatooine simply as the sandpeople. .

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The Tuskens didn’t permit close study of themselves, discouraging potential observers by methodsas effective as they were uncivilized. A few xenologists thought they must be related to the jawas. Even fewer hypothesized that the jawas were actually the mature form of the sandpeople, but this theory was discounted by the majority of serious scientists.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Both races affected tight clothing to shield them from Tatooine’s twin dose of solar radiation, but there most comparisons ended. Instead of heavy. woven cloaks like the jawas wore, the sandpeople wrapped themselves mummylike in endless swathings and bandages and loose bits of cloth.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Where the jawas feared everything, a Tusken Raider feared little. The sandpeople were larger, stronger, and far more aggressive. Fortunately for the human colonists of Tatooine, they were not very numerous and elected to pursue their nomadic existencein some of Tatooine’s most desolate regions. Contact between human and Tusken, therefore, was in-frequent and uneasy, and they murdered no more than a handful of humans per year. Since the human population had claimed its share of Tuskens, not alwayswith reason, a peace of a sort existed between the two—as long as neither side gained an advantage.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: One of the pair felt that that unstable condition had temporarily shifted in his favor, and he was about

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: to take full advantage of it as he raised his rifle toward the landspeeder. But his companion grabbedthe weapon and shoved down on it before it could be fired. This set off a violent argument between the two. And, as they traded vociferous opinions in a language consisting mostly of consonants, the landspeeder sped on its way.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Either because the speeder had passed out of range or because the second Tusken had convinced the other, the two broke off the discussion and scrambled down the back side of the high ridge. Snuffling and a shifting of weight took place at the ridge bottom as the two Banthas stirred at the approach of their masters. Each was as large as a small dinosaur, with brighteyes and long, thick fur. They hissed anxiously as the two sandpeople approached, then mounted them from knee to saddle.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: With a kick Banthas rose, Moving slowly but with enormous strides, the two massive horned creatures swept down the back of the rugged bluff, urgedon by their anxious, equally outrageous mahouts,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “It’s him, all right,” Luke declared with mixed anger and satisfaction as the tiny tripodal form came intoview. The speeder banked and swung down onto the floor of a huge sandstone canyon. Luke slipped his tifle out from behind the seat and swung it over his shoulder. “Come round in front of him, Threepio,” he instructed. :

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “With pleasure, sir.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The Artoo unit obviously noted their approach, but made no move to escape; it could hardly have outrun the landspeeder anyway. Artoo simply halted as soon as it detected them and waited until the craft swung around in a smooth arc. Threepio came to a sharp halt, sending up a low cloud of sand on the smaller robot’s right. Then the whine from the landspeeder’s engine dropped to a low idling hum as Threepio put it in parking mode. A last sigh and the craft stopped completely.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: After finishing a cautious survey of the canyon, Luke led his companion out onto the gravelly surface and up to Artoo Detoo. “Just where,” he inquired sharply, “did you think you were going?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A feeble whistle issued from the apologetic robot, but it was Threepio and not the recalcitrant rover who was abruptly doing most of the talking.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Master Luke here is now your rightful owner, Artoo, How could you just amble away from him like this? Now that he’s found you, let’s have no more of this ‘Obi-wan Kenobi’ gibberish. I don’t know where you picked that up—or that melodramatic hologram, either.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Artoo started to beep in protest, but Threepio’s indignation was too great to permit excuses. “And don’ttalk to me about your mission. What rot! You're fortunate Master Luke doesn’t blast you into a million pieces right here and now.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Not much chance of that,” admitted Luke, a bit overwhelmed by Threepio’s casual vindictiveness. “Come on—it’s getting late.” He eyed the rapidly tising suns. “I just hope we can get back before Uncle Owen really lets go.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “If you don’t mind my saying so,” Threepio suggested, apparently unwilling that the Artoo unit shouldget off so easily, “I think you ought to deactivate the little fugitive until you’ve gotten him safely back in the garage.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “No. He’s not going to try anything.” Luke studied the softly beeping ’droid sternly. “I hope he’s learned his lesson. There’s no need to—”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Without warning the Artoo unit suddenly leaped off the ground—no mean feat considering the weakness of the spring mechanisms in his three thick legs.His cylindrical body was twisting and spinning as he let out a frantic symphony of whistles, hoots, and electronic exclamations.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke was tired, not alarmed. “What is it? What’s wrong with him now?” He was beginning to see how

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio’s patience could be worn thin. He had had about enough of this addled instrument himself.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Undoubtedly the Artoo unit had acquired the holo of the girl by accident, then used it to entice Luke into removing his restraining module. Threepio probably had the right attitude. Still, once Luke got itscircuits realigned and its logic couplings cleaned, it would make a perfectly serviceable farm unit. Only ... if that was the case, then why was Threepio looking around so anxiously?

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: ‘Oh my, sir. Artoo claims there are several creatures of unknown type approaching from the south-east.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: That could be another attempt by Artoo to distract them, but Luke couldn’t take the chance. Instantly he had his rifle off his shoulder and had activated the energy cell. He examined the horizon in the indicated direction and saw nothing. But then, sandpeople were experts at making themselves unseeable.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke suddenly realized exactly how far out they were, how much ground the landspeeder had covered that morning. “I’ve never been out in this direction this far from the farm before,” he informed Threepio. “There are some awfully strange things living out here. Not all of them have been classified. It’s better to treat anything as dangerous until determined otherwise. Of course, if it’s something utterly new .. .”His curiosity prodded him. In any case, this was probably just another ruse of Artoo Detoo’s. “Let’s take alook,” he decided.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Moving cautiously forward and keeping his rifle ready, he led Threepio toward the crest of a nearby high dune. At the same time he took care not to let Artoo out of his sight.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Once at the top he lay flat and traded his rifle for the macrobinoculars. Below, another canyon spread out before them, rising to a wind-weathered wall of tust and ocher. Advancing the binocs slowly across the canyon floor, he settled unexpectedly on two tethered shapes. Banthas—and riderless!

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Did you say something, sir?” wheezed Threepio, struggling up behind Luke. His locomotors were not designed for such outer climbing and scrambling,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Banthas, all right,” Luke whispered over his shoulder, not considering in the excitement of the momentthat Threepio might not know a Bantha from a panda.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: He looked back into the eyepieces, refocusing slightly. “Wait . . . it’s sandpeople, sure. I see one of them.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Something dark suddenly blocked his sight. For a moment he thought that a rock might have moved in front of him. Irritably he dropped the binoculars and reached out to move the blinding object aside. His hand touched something like soft metal.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: It was a bandaged leg about as big around as both of Luke’s together. Shocked, he looked up . . . and up. The towering figure glaring down at him was no jawa. It had seemingly erupted straight from the sand.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio took a startled step backward and found no footing. As gyros whined in protest the tall robot tumbled backward down the side of the dune. Frozen in place, Luke heard steadily fading bangs and rattles as Threepio bounced down the steep slope behindhim.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: As the moment of confrontation passed, the Tusken let out a terrifying grunt of fury and pleasure and brought down his heavy gaderffii. The double-edged ax would have cleaved Luke’s skull neatly in two, except that he threw the rifle up in a gesture more instinctive than calculated. His weapon deflected the blow, but would never do so again. Made from cannibalized freighter plating the huge ax shattered the barrel and made metallic confetti of the gun’s delicate insides.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke scrambled backward and found himself against a steep drop. The Raider stalked him slowly, weapon held high over its rag-enclosed head. It uttered a gruesome, chuckling laugh, the sound made

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: all the more inhuman by the distortion effect of its gridlike sandfilter.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke tried to view his situation objectively, as he had been instructed to do in survival school. Trouble was, his mouth was dry, his hands were shaking, and he was paralyzed with fear. With the Raider in front of him and a probably fatal drop behind, something else in his mind took over and opted for the least painful response. He fainted.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: None of the Raiders noticed Artoo Detoo as the tiny robot forced himself into a small alcove in the rocks near the landspeeder, One of them was carrying the inert form of Luke. He dumped the unconscious youth in a heap next to the speeder, then joined bis fellows as they began swarming over the open craft.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Supplies and spare parts were thrown in all directions. From time to time the plundering would beinterrupted as several of them quibbled or fought over a particularly choice bit of booty.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Unexpectedly, distribution of the landspeeder’s contents ceased, and with frightening speed the Raidersbecame part of the desertscape, looking in all directions.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A lost breeze idled absently down the canyon. Far off to the west, something howled. A rolling, booming drone ricocheted off canyon walls and crawlednervously up and down a gorgon scale.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The sandpeople remained poised a moment longer. Then they were uttering loud grunts and moans of fright as they rushed to get away from the highly visible landspeeder.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The shivering howl sounded again, nearer this time. By now the sandpéople were halfway to their waiting Banthas, that were likewise lowing tensely andtugging at their tethers.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Although the sound held no meaning for Artoo Detoo, the little *droid tried to squeeze himself even deeper into the almost-cave. The booming howl came closer. Judging by the way the sandpeople had reacted, something monstrous beyond imagining had to be be-

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: hind that rolling cry. Something monstrous and murder-bent which might not have the sense to distinguish between edible organics and inedible ma-chines.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Not even the dust of their passing remained to mark where the Tusken Raiders had only minutes before been dismembering the interior of the landspeeder. Artoo Detoo shut down all but vital func-tions, trying to minimize noise and light as a swishing sound grew gradually audible. Moving toward the landspeeder, the creature appeared above the top of a nearby dune. ...

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: LIV

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: IT was tall, but hardly monstrous. Artoo frowned inwardly as he checked ocular circuitry and reactivated his innards,

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The monster looked very much like an old man. He was clad in a shabby cloak and loose robes hung with a few small straps, packs, and unrecognizable instruments. Artoo searched the human’s wake but detected no evidence of a pursuing nightmare. Nor did the man appear threatened. Actually, Artoo thought, he looked kind of pleased.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: It was impossible to tell where the odd arrival’s overlapping attire ended and his skin began. That aged visage blended into the sand-stroked cloth, and his beard appeared but an extension of the loose threads covering his upper chest.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Hints of extreme climates other than desert, of ultimate cold and humidity, were etched into that seamedface. A questing beak of nose, like a high rock, protruded outward from a flashflood of wrinkles andscars, The eyes bordering it were a liquid crystalazure. The man smiled through sand and dust and

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: beard, squinting at the sight of the crumpled form lying quietly alongside the landspeeder.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Convinced that the sandpeople had been the victims of an auditory delusion of some kind—conveniently ignoring the fact that he had experienced italso—and likewise assured that this stranger meant Luke no harm, Artoo shifted his position slightly, trying to obtain a better view. The sound produced bya tiny pebble he dislodged was barely perceptible to his electronic sensors, but the man whirled as if shot. He stared straight at Artoo’s alcove, still smiling gently.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: ‘Hello there,” he called in a deep, surpringly cheerful voice. “Come here, my little friend. No need to be afraid.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Something forthright and reassuring was in that voice. In any case, the association of an unknown human was preferable to remaining isolated in this wasteland. Waddling out into the sunlight, Artoo made his way over to where Luke lay sprawled. The robot’s bartellike body inclined forward as he examined the limp form. Whistles and beeps of concern came from within.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Walking over, the old man bent beside Luke and reached out to touch his forehead, then his temple. Shortly. the unconscious youth was stirring and mumbling like a dreaming sleeper.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Don’t worry,” the human told Artoo, “he'll be all tight.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: As if to confirm this opinion, Luke blinked, stared upward uncomprehendingly, and muttered, “What happened?’

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Rest easy, son,” the man instructed him as he sat back on his heels. “You’ve had a busy day.” Again the boyish grin. “You’re mighty lucky your head’s still attached to the rest of you.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke looked around, his gaze coming to rest on the elderly face hovering above him. Recognition did wonders for his condition.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Ben ... it’s got to be!” A sudden remembrance

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: made him look around fearfully. But there was no sign of sandpeople. Slowly he raised his body to a sitting position. “Ben Kenobi. . . am I glad to see you!”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Rising, the old man surveyed the canyon floor and rolling rimwall above. One foot played with the sand. “The Jundland wastes are not to be traveled lightly. It’s the misguided traveler who tempts the Tuskens’ hospitality.” His gaze went back to his patient. “Tell me, young man, what brings you out thisfar into nowhere?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke indicated Artoo Detoo. “This little ’droid. For a while I thought he’d gone crazy, claiming he was searching for a former master, Now I don’t think so. I’ve never seen such devotion in a ’droid—misguided or otherwise. There seems to be no stoppinghim; he even resorted to tricking me.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke’s gaze shifted upward. “He claims to be the property of someone called Obi-wan Kenobi.” Luke watched closely, but the man showed no reaction. “Is that a relative of yours? My uncle thinks he was a real person. Or is it just some unimportant bit of scrambled information that got shifted into his primary performance bank?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: An introspective frown did remarkable things to that sandlbasted face, Kenobi appeared to ponder the question, scratching absently at his scruffy beard. “Obi-wan. Kenobi!,” he recited. “Obi-wan .. . now, that’s a name I haven’t heard in a Jong time. A long time. Most curious.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “My uncle said he was dead,” Luke supplied helpfully.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Oh, he’s not dead,” Kenobi corrected him easily. “Not yet, not yet.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Luke climbed excitedly to his feet, afl thoughts of Tusken Raiders forgotten now. “You know him, then?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: A smile of perverse youthfulness split that collage of wrinkled skin and beard. “Of course I know him: he’s me. Just as you probably suspected, Luke. I

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: haven’t gone by the name Obi-wan, though, since before you were born.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Then,” Luke essayed, gesturing at Artoo Detoo, “this "droid does belong to you, as he claims.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Now, that’s the peculiar part,” an openly puzzled Kenobi confessed, regarding the silent robot. “I can’t seem to remember owning a "droid, least of all a modern Artoo unit. Most interesting, most interesting.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Something drew the old man’s gaze suddenly to the brow of nearby cliffs. “I think it’s best we make use of your landspeeder some. The sandpeople are easily startled, but they'll soon return in greater numbers. A landspeeder’s not a prize readily conceded, and after all, jawas they’re not.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Placing both hands over his mouth in a peculiar fashion, Kenobi inhaled deeply and let out an unearthly howl that made Luke jump. “That ought to keep any laggards running for a while yet,” the old man concluded with satisfaction.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “That’s a krayt dragon call!” Luke gaped in astonishment “How did you do that?”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “Pil show you sometime, son. It’s not too hard. Just takes the right attitude, a set of well-used vocal cords, and a lot of wind. Now, if you were an imperial bureaucrat, I could teach you right off, but you’re not.”He scanned the cliff-spine again. “And I don’t think this is the time or place for it.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: “I won’t argue that.” Luke was rubbing at the back of his head. “Let’s get started.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: That was when Artoo let out a pathetic beep and whirled. Luke couldn’t interpret the electronic squeal, but he suddenly comprehended the reason behind it. “Threepio.” Luke exclaimed, worriedly. Artoo was already moving as fast as possible away from the landspeeder. “Come on, Ben.”

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: The little robot led them to the edge of a large sandpit. It stopped there, pointing downward and squeaking mournfully. Luke saw where Artoo was pointing, then started cautiously down the smooth, shifting slope while Kenobi followed effortlessly.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
paragraph: Threepio lay in the sand at the base of the slope down which he had rolled and tumbled. His casing was dented and badly mangled, One arm lay broken and bent a short distance away.

title: Star Wars
Author: George Lucas
